Second SIGINT: forcefully terminate libtrap and thus don't send EOF message to the connected client (useful if the client is not responding).

New feature: Overflow detection
When processing fields in records, the data type overflow can happen when using arithmetical operations. In that case, this situation is detected and "emergency export" is invoked. The impacted record is sent out before modification and replaced with new data.
The overflow check is implemented for these aggregation functions:

SUM

The current implementation is able to detect data type oveflow in both directions (negative, positive) for UR_TYPEs marked as UR_TYPE_INT(8|16|32|64), UR_TYPE_UINT(8|16|32|64).

New feature: Record sending with a dedicated thread.
Interface settings or network properties like latency can affect the throughput of the module processing. A new dedicated thread was implemented for that case and has its own dedicated data space for records (messages) to send. This improves the processing power because sending the record (message) is no longer the task of processing thread.
The processing thread only "mark_msg_to_send"  which moves the record to the data space of sending thread and continue processing another received record.

This PR replaces original storage and look-up mechanism with ip_prefix_search feature that was recently (and finally) merged into UniRec. This feature should have log complexity for look-up, which should be better for longer lists of IP ranges.

The changes seems sound to me and from architecture point of view, this makes a lot of sense.
Since @cejkato2 asked explicitly about performance:

This feature should have log complexity for look-up, which should be better for longer lists of IP ranges.

Judging by the resize strategy when loading the networks from configuration file, I guess that the network count will be usually in the lower tens in which case the sequential matching would be most likely faster than random access pattern introduced by binary search (random access to RAM is surprisingly slower than sequential and iirc to caches too - I remember reading a nice comparison quite recently which, of course, I can't find now).
All-in-all, my guestimate is that the potential performance hit will be negligible (at least its absolute value) and unless the speed is super-critical I'd go with cleaner code and better software architecture. Otherwise, benchmark of real-world workload is unavoidable I am afraid ;)

column13: blacklist2idea: Simplify the nonvalid XML condition
column20:
In 3c7ebb2 a hotfix was created
for nonvalid blacklist hostname and URL representation. The condition
used there was (x is not None and len(x)), which is equivalent
to (x) as both None and iterable of length 0 are treated as False.
The simplified condition works exactly the same in these cases. There
still remains the case of non-iterables, where the code will fail
(as list cannot be constructed from non-iterables), but the previous
would also. To be extra safe there, one should do like
try: y = list(x); except TypeError: y = list(); but according to [1],
xml.etree.ElementTree.parse() should return ElementTree instance which
should only evaluate to iterable or None when passed to list constructor,
so y = list(x) if (x) else list(); is probably enough. Based on [1],
xml.etree.ElementTree is not safe for untrusted data anyways.
Well, writing robust code in Python is hard.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3.8/library/xml.etree.elementtree.html

This is a draft of an extension of liburfilter to support optimized
filtering of integer values like this:
DST_PORT in [1, 234, 123, 80, 443]
The array (in brackets [ and ])is parsed, sorted, and finnaly in
evalAST() searched using bsearch().
This should be faster than complicated filter like this:
DST_PORT == 1 or DST_PORT == 234 or DST_PORT == 123 or DST_PORT == 80 or DST_PORT == 443
Note: this patch also adds a basic test in cmocka. To run it,
libcmocka-devel (or equivalent) must be installed.
The patch should be improved:

distinguish signed / unsigned numbers (right now everything is
compared as uint64_t)
add missing UniRec types like ipaddr, macaddr, time

column20:
Googletest integration
This framework will help us create clearer unit tests. It is intended for C / C ++ code.
How integration is set up
The Googletest repository is downloaded as a submodule, which must be compiled as a library. It is not recommended to have Googletest installed, see FAQ. So during the make check the library will be compiled once. If you modify the unit test or add another one, the library will not be recompiled. Neither tests nor the library will be compiled during make.
By default, googletests will be used during make check. Even during configuration, no flag needs to be set. (Because it makes more sense to implicitly use all the tests that are available). If the user downloads the repository using a git clone without the --recurse-submodules flag, then ./configure will report a warning that googletests will be skipped. During the make check, the user will then see "skipped" for the tests to make it clear that some tests are not in use.
Cons and Pros
Primer
From my point of view, it's nice that the tests don't have to be registered. Dependencies are handled only in Makefile.am, and even in the main.cpp file, other .cpp tests are not included.
However, there may be a problem with a longer translation. It may take a few tens of seconds to translate the library. There's probably not much you can do about it.
It may make more sense to translate a library as dynamic than static... Maybe I'll change it.
Other
A directory googletest_example is here temporarily. It contains a template for the correct compilation and running of googletests. Once a number of tests are integrated in this repository, this template will no longer be needed.
The example was tested on Centos8.
